    as recently as; 'I spoke to him only an hour ago' (r#00010017)
    without anybody else; 'the child stayed home alone' (r#00154032)
    to a complete degree or to the full or entire extent; 'he was wholly convinced'; 'entirely satisfied with the meal'; 'it was completely different from what we expected'; 'was completely at fault'; 'a totally new situation'; 'the directions were all wrong'; 'It was not altogether her fault'; 'an altogether new approach'; (`whole' is often used informally for `wholly' as in 'a whole new idea') (r#00007075)
    without any others being included or involved; 'was entirely to blame'; 'a school devoted entirely to the needs of problem children'; 'he works for Mr. Smith exclusively'; 'did it solely for money'; 'the burden of proof rests on the prosecution alone'; 'a privilege granted only to him' (r#00007655)

EXCLUSIVUS (a) (aps---mn1-)
    not separated into parts or shares; constituting an undivided unit; 'an undivided interest in the property'; 'a full share' (a#00482536)
    excluding much or all; especially all but a particular group or minority; 'exclusive clubs'; 'an exclusive restaurants and shops' (a#01791543)
    exclusive of anyone or anything else; 'she alone believed him'; 'cannot live by bread alone'; 'I'll have this car and this car only' (a#01791800)
    exclusive to a center; especially a center of influence; 'inner regions of the organization'; 'inner circles of government' (a#01791994)

EXCURSATIO (n) (n-s---fn3-)
    judiciousness in avoiding harm or danger; 'he exercised caution in opening the door'; 'he handled the vase with care' (n#04349454)
    an official document issued by a government and conferring on the recipient the rank of an officer in the armed forces (n#04864373)
    a conspicuous success; 'that song was his first hit and marked the beginning of his career' (n#00037139)
    a general course along which something has a tendency to develop; 'I couldn't follow the direction of his thoughts'; 'his ideals determined the direction of his career'; 'they proposed a new direction for the firm' (n#04698475)
    a quantity of explosive to be set off at one time; 'this cartridge has a powder charge of 50 grains' (n#02423572)
    a design or image depicted on a shield (n#02423808)
    artillery designed to shoot upward at airplanes (n#02192030)
    placed between moving parts to allow them to move easily (n#02271838)
    the state of being in good working order and ready for operation; 'put the ships into comission'; 'the motor was out of commission' (n#10091540)
    the process of combustion of inflammable materials producing heat and light and (often) smoke; 'fire was one of our ancestors' first discoveries' (n#09686541)
    a sudden sharp noise; 'the crack of a whip'; 'he heard the cracking of the ice' (n#05495688)
    intense adverse criticism; 'Clinton directed his fire at Jesse Helms' (n#05033377)
    characteristic way of bearing one's body: 'stood with good posture' (n#03907971)
    a venture off the beaten path; 'a sally into the wide world beyond his home' (n#00512462)
    the work of caring for or attending to someone or something; 'no medical care was required'; 'the old car needed constant attention' (n#00428745)
    an operational flight by a single aircraft (as in a military operation) (n#00197295)
    (psychoanalysis) the libidinal energy invested in some idea or person or object; 'Freud thought of cathexis as a psychic analog of an electrical charge' (n#06665341)
    azione ostile e lesiva, volta a danneggiare o minacciare qualcuno o qualcosa; attacco alla nuova società (n#W0003119)
    a fringe of banged hair (cut short squarely across the forehead) (n#04082970)
    relevant relation or interconnection: 'those issues have no bearing on our situation' (n#09934616)
    a person committed to your care; 'the teacher led her charges across the street' (n#07150262)
    a strong current of air; 'the tree was bent almost double by the gust' (n#07804970)
    a cause for feeling concern; 'his major care was the illness of his wife' (n#05578801)
    a purified and potent form of cocaine that is smoked rather than snorted (n#02514673)
    a witty saying (n#05351072)
    the act of setting and holding a course; 'a new council was installed under the direction of the king' (n#00521002)
    a long narrow depression in a surface (n#10021740)
    an assertion that someone is guilty of a fault or offence; 'the newspaper published charges that Jones was guilty of drunken driving' (n#05045982)
    a formulation adopted in tackling a problem; 'his approach to every problem is to draw up a list of pros and cons' (n#00601680)
    the responsibility of a guardian or keeper; 'he left his car in my keeping' (n#00523477)

    strike or cancel by or as if by rubbing or crossing out; 'scratch out my name on that list' (v#01067122)
    make excuses for (v#00606341)
    proceed or get along; 'How is she doing in her new job?' 'How are you making out in graduate school?' 'He's come a long way' (v#01785226)
    reach a destination, either real or abstract; 'We hit Detroit by noon'; 'The water reached the doorstep'; 'We barely made the plane'; 'I have to hit the MAC machine before the weekend starts' (v#01379952)
    reach in time; 'We barely made the plane' (v#01380463)
    appear to begin an activity; 'He made to speak but said nothing i the end'; 'She made a if to say hello to us' (v#01460612)
    give the appearance or impression of; 'cut a nice figure' (v#01460792)
    cut off and stop; 'The bicyclist was cut out by the van' (v#00987838)
    separate with or as if with an instrument; 'Cut the rope' (v#01069335)
    reach a goal, e.g., 'make the first team'; 'We made it!' 'She may not make the grade' (v#01381076)
    write all the required information onto a form; 'fill out this questionnaire, please!'; 'make out a form' (v#00690164)
    simplify the form of a mathematical equation of expression by substituting one term for another (v#01545250)
    form by cutting out; 'Picasso cut out a piece of paper in the shape of a guitar' (v#01071376)
    hit against; come into sudden contact with; 'The arrow hit the target'; 'The car hit a tree' (v#00841893)
    constitute the essence of; 'Clothes make the man' (v#01788243)
    to compose or represent:'This wall forms the background of the stage setting'; 'The branches made a roof'; 'This makes a fine introduction' (v#01788486)
    trim carefully; of fingernails (v#00029909)
    divide at random; 'cut a deck of cards' (v#01071905)
    cause to do; cause to act in a specified manner: 'The ads induced me to buy a VCR'; 'My children finally got me to buy a computer'; 'My wife made me buy a new sofa' (v#00523422)
    divide a deck of cards into two parts to make selection difficult; 'Wayne cut' (v#01072023)
    pass through or across; 'The boat cut the water' (v#01307063)
    pass directly and often in haste; 'We cut through the neighbor's yard to get home sooner' (v#01307198)
    undergo meiosis; 'The cells reduce' (v#01074120)
    remove something concrete, as by lifting, pushing, taking off, etc; or remove something abstract; 'remove a threat'; 'remove a wrapper'; 'Remove the dirty dishes from the table'; 'take the gun from your pocket' (v#00118898)

EXISTUMATIO (n) (n-s---fn3-)
    an official award (as for bravery or service) usually given as formal public statement (n#05029189)
    an official recognition of merit; 'although he didn't win the prize he did get special mention' (n#05029345)
    a rationalized mental attitude (n#04697893)
    educational recognition that a course of studies has been successfully completed (n#00038052)
    an item on a list or in a sequence; 'in the second place'; 'moved from third to fifth position' (n#04868096)
    the capacity to assess situations or circumstances shrewdly and to draw sound conclusions (n#03831455)
    the place where some action occurs; 'the police returned to the scene of the crime' (n#06367294)
    the graphic or photographic representation of a visual percept; 'he painted scenes from everyday life'; 'figure 2 shows photographic and schematic views of the equipment' (n#03280931)
    the painted structures of a stage set that are intended to suggest a particular locale; 'they worked all night painting the scenery' (n#03281179)
    an indicator that orients you generally; 'it is used as a reference for comparing the heating and the electrical energy involved' (n#05417191)
    a publication (or a passage from a publication) that is referred to; 'he carried an armful of references back to his desk'; 'he spent hours looking for the source of that quotation' (n#05417541)
    an entry on a list of persons who contributed to a film or written work (n#04785467)
    the range of vision; 'out of sight of land' (n#04355068)
    a way of regarding situations or topics etc; 'consider what follows from the positivist view' (n#04706473)
    the range of interest or activity that can be anticipated; 'It is beyond the horizon of present knowledge' (n#03994627)
    a range of mental vision; 'in his sight she could do no wrong' (n#04707583)
    the process of recognizing something or someone by remembering (n#04445171)
    the act of putting something in a certain place or location (n#00680814)
    a passage or expression that is quoted (n#04960176)

EXPLACABILIS (a) (aps---cn3i)

EXPLANABILIS (a) (aps---cn3i)

EXPLANATE (r) (rp--------)
    in an intelligible manner; 'the foreigner spoke to us quite intelligibly' (r#00199032)
    without doubt or question; 'they were clearly lost'; 'history has clearly shown the folly of that policy' (r#00037949)
    unmistakably; 'the answer is obviously wrong'; 'she was in bed and evidently in great pain'; 'he was manifestly too important to leave off the guest list'; 'it is all patently nonsense'; 'she has apparently been living here for some time'; 'I thought he owned the property, but apparently not'; 'You are plainly wrong'; (`plain' is often used informally for `plainly' as in 'he is plain stubborn') (r#00038108)
    from appearances alone; 'irrigation often produces bumper crops from apparently desert land'; 'the child is seemingly healthy but the doctor is concerned'; 'had been ostensibly frank as to his purpose while really concealing it'-Thomas Hardy; 'on the face of it the problem seems minor' (r#00038718)
    clear to the mind; with distinct mental discernment; 'it's distinctly possible'; 'I could clearly see myself in his situation' (r#00177915)
    and nothing more; 'I was merely asking'; 'it is simply a matter of time'; 'just a scratch'; 'he was only a child'; 'hopes that last but a moment' (r#00003737)
    absolutely; altogether; really; 'we are simply broke' (r#00003982)
    in a simple manner; without extravagance or embellishment; 'she was dressed plainly'; 'they lived very simply' (r#00004070)
    (intensifier) absolutely; 'I just can't take it anymore'; 'he was just grand as Romeo'; 'it's simply beautiful!' (r#00242516)
    in an easily perceptible manner; 'could be seen clearly under the microscope'; 'She cried loud and clear' (r#00280947)
    completely; 'read the book clear to the end'; 'slept clear through the night'; 'there were open fields clear to the horizon' (r#00281114)
    to a distinct degree; 'urbanization in Spain is distinctly correlated with a fall in reproductive rate' (r#00302061)
    in a distinct and distinguishable manner; 'the subtleties of this distinctly British occasion' (r#00302221)

EXSIGNATUS (a) (aps---mn1-)

EXSIGNO (n) (n-s---fn1-)
    form or shape by cutting or incising; 'cut out paper dolls' (v#01198965)
    form by probing, penetrating, or digging; 'cut a hole'; 'cut trenches'; 'The sweat cut little rivulets into her face' (v#01199121)
    bring to public notice by writing, with praise or condemnation; 'The New York Times wrote him up last week'; 'Did your boss write you up?' (v#00725173)
    proceed or get along; 'How is she doing in her new job?' 'How are you making out in graduate school?' 'He's come a long way' (v#01785226)
    create by recording electronically; 'cut a disk'; 'cut a CD' (v#01200343)
    record a performance on; 'cut a record' (v#01200482)
    bring down or defeat, in sports (v#00746523)
    produce a literary work; 'She composed a poem'; 'He wrote four novels' (v#01164896)
    grow through the gums; 'The new tooth is cutting' (v#00064692)
    separate with or as if with an instrument; 'Cut the rope' (v#01069335)
    shorten as if by severing the edges or ends of; 'cut my hair' (v#00393651)
    make a recording of: 'cut the songs' (v#01200618)
    lessen the strength or flavor of a solution or mixture; 'cut bourbon' (v#00154752)
    make mention of; 'She observed that his presentation took up too much time'; 'They noted that it was a fine day to go sailing' (v#00689564)
    hit (a ball) with a spin so that it turns in the opposite direction; 'cut a pingpong ball' (v#00968907)
    write all the required information onto a form; 'fill out this questionnaire, please!'; 'make out a form' (v#00690164)
    make a written note of; 'she noted everything the teacher said that morning' (v#00690367)
    write or name the letters that comprise the conventionally accepted form of (a word or part of a word); 'He spelled the word wrong in this letter' (v#01166173)
    give the appearance or impression of; 'cut a nice figure' (v#01460792)
    detect with the senses; 'The fleeing convicts were picked out of the darkness by the watchful prison guards'; 'I can't make out the faces in this photograph' (v#01501559)
    move, as of a fist in boxing; 'his opponent cut upward toward his chin' (v#01441424)
    divide at random; 'cut a deck of cards' (v#01071905)
    divide a deck of cards into two parts to make selection difficult; 'Wayne cut' (v#01072023)
    pass through or across; 'The boat cut the water' (v#01307063)
    pass directly and often in haste; 'We cut through the neighbor's yard to get home sooner' (v#01307198)
    stop filming; 'cut a movie scene' (v#01270266)

EXTRUNCIS (a) (aps---cn3i)
